post.body: Hello ZeroMe!
Neat I can follow my own posts!
Friendly reminder that if you love something, it is your duty to help it flourish and blossom!
i've never understood social network sites or what you are supposed to post on them so here is a picture of monster girls and a happy family unit.
had significant difficulties today with getting 0net to update zites (over tor). it took about 3 hours to see anything new. but it seems to work now.
It's actually kind of cool to see so much activity from China here. I don't really see that in other networks with similar anti-censorship goals. Is there something special about ZeroNet?
well this is something
if i host some super awesome distributed site will i become rich and popular?
I've been having significant difficulties receiving site updates over the last few days over tor. Is it some kind of attack? Did I break something? ;__;

when www dies, so will zeroboard. why on earth does zeroboard require access to www resources? i thought the whole point of 0net was we didn't need centralized web anymore. is this the only "official" 0net service that has www dependencies?
every blurry image here that hasn't been loaded yet looks highly sexual until it loads and then its something completely innocent. i must have a really lewd mind. am i the only lewdie?
a couple months ago i made a really nifty site which sums up my ZeroNet experience as a whole, hopefully its accessible: http://127.0.0.1:43110/13vuCMvgVBtaB6wi5JCsNEbeyKfnHZLeE9/

it seems to take nearly 1 hour and 30 minutes in order for ZeroNet to integrate in the network and start actually updating zites when tor only mode is enabled. in comparison it takes about 12 minutes for my i2p router to become integrated well enough to reach most hidden services.

both represent a vision of a global decentralized network.
one offers real anonymity.
the other has better looking .css

wow, a decentralized and censorship resistant network! finally anyone can say what they want without being silenced and the state can't do anything about it!

thats a really cool idea that more people should jump onboard for! i'm going to go there and whinge and moan at the people who designed it because they refuse to remove the content i don't agree with!

someone needs to research a way to weaponize all the unsolicited emails that get sent every day to inboxes which nobody checks on anymore. all the bandwidth and cpu cycles and electricity wasted must amount to something incredibly powerful, if you could convert it into the right form and focus it on a single point.

PSA: if you download a file from a user, and then you mute/block that user, you still have that file saved on your computer, and you are most likely still helping to distribute that file until you remove it.

PSA: Good p2p citizens understand the importance of giving back to the network.

Download and distribute optional files; download newly published sites; keep old sites updated; keep ZeroNet updated and running even when you're not using it.

The hdd space and bandwith you contribute go directly into keeping the network healthy and its content accessible to others.

today we are running a special, two #cute girls for the price of one. double trigger warning this time.
if visiting your site once automatically signs me up for notifications for every new post that's made there, i am not going to seed it to others

I just exercised my power to edit a post I made. I think the change is a good one...
It really creeps me out that I or anyone can simply go back and rewrite something they wrote to say something completely different. How do I know the posts I read today are the same posts that will be propogated tomorrow?
Why does the ability to edit a post that I made unsettling?

oh look, someone posted something really coo-


ThisIsWhyINeedDecentralization

I don't really see the need for such unplesantries. It's well within a person's right to mute others, but I don't see the need to boast about it. It IS rude.
As far as viewing content you don't like, I've only encountered one other person with "loli" in his name, and he does a good job at identifying whether what he's posting is sfw or not. And I also am trying now to do a good job identifying the content of things I post so people can decide if they want to load those files to their computer.
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HmJ7GadjdiQUPevaK7QXVrK4nhyCp1fSj/?Post/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd/1488912274

Tor-only-mode kicked on right away for me today. Usually it takes nearly 2 hours before I can publish content or receive updates for sites. What did I do differently? I deleted a bunch of sites I was seeding! I have a strong suspicion that the 500mb english antilibrary file played a role in my problem somehow. Hopefully this means the end of my 2 hour long wait times.

it puts a button under your post that said (Bad Ugly) and (Spam). i couldn't bring myself to press either of them so i dont know what they do ;_;

@Martinv: i get the impression a lot of people who use zeronet are too sensitive and want to hide all the things that scare them. not a good attitude to have on a network that is designed to resist censorship and keep content alive. but those tools should still be useful against really obnoxious people
not yet! i think the developers want to implement some kind of uri so people can post something like zeronet://foo.bit

@Martinv: its not bad to have the tools, and would certainly be useful for cleaning up a messy zerome feed. i was just remarking on a general trend i've noticed of people on zeronet wanting to block and censor things
@Martinv: no, i was simply making a comment based on observations i have made!
your profile pic is pleasing to look at
@Border0464fred: if you dont want to seed certain things then don't enable this on those places... that is the point, you seed what you like. it is your duty.
you're a madman!
https://geti2p.net/

@Φάραν: lemme know if you run into any roadblocks. its not so difficult to install it and get it running, but lots of things like how it handles dns and configuring the proxy in your web browser can be really confusing for new users
@Arkre: Sensible I guess. I can't think of anything else offhand.  I'm just glad this is working for them.

I only found out you could send processes to the background like that in the last couple weeks. I'm sure most neckbeards already knew, but finding out about it saved me so many headaches. If you forget to do & when you launch it, you can also pause the process with Ctrl + Z, then do "bg" to send it to the background, and then disown it to get the same effect.

@Loligod: it should not after you disown it! This isn't necessarily useful information with IPFS, but I've had to deal with other software that requires input from the user after it starts up, and this behavior throws a wrench in launching it with nohup.
@Loligod: better stick to your method then as far as IPFS is concerned. And I only found out about this a couple weeks ago so there could be shortcomings I haven't discovered yet.

@Rebelb0y11: i experienced that a few minutes after i posted this actually, and it was really conflicting.

If a single person has the power to censor people this network so easily, then there's really no value to it, is there? i guess nofish can just close up shop and abandon ZeroNet! It was a good effort everyone! Nice try! On to the next big thing! I heared about a great network called Friendster, we should all migrate to that instead!
someone please tell me if it's not supposed to take that long, because i did not exaggerate and it consistently takes about that long for everything to become useable

@Firebox: i notice that at launch, tor.exe continually sucks 25% cpu for as long as zeronet can't update sites or publish content. it ceases this once everything works normally. maybe tomorrow i'll peek at the console and see what it says while it does this...

oh, it seems to do this for 90 minutes for some reason? no idea why it would suddenly stop doing it and work after that length of time: Connect error: ProxyConnectionError: Error connecting to SOCKS5 proxy 127.0.0.1:49050: [Errno 10061] [Error 10061] No connection could be made because the target machine actively refused it. in ConnectionServer.py line 139 > Connection.py line 97 > TorManager.py line 287 > socks.py line 674
@Hexkey: i dont think so...

@Firebox: i deleted zeronet and redownloaded the windows bundle thingy, but that didn't solve anything. i would do your solution, Firebox, but from what i understand doing it this way prevents ZeroNet from reaching other .onion addresses and doesn't seem a good resolution.
@Hexkey: zeroboard clones/substitutes don't seem to need this, but no one seems to use them in favor of zeroboard.

looks like you found me

do you not have the option of running with your own router? you may be stuck with their modem, but you should still be able to rock your own router. also it sounds like they are charging you out the ass for renting their router from them. that may be why your monthly service costs are so high.

at best you can favorite the ones you like so they stick to the top of the page (this is browser dependent and wont work if you disabled local storage). it can be very annoying manually deleting each site on the list that you are not interested in seeding.

sounds like the person you talked to squeezed an extra buck out of you. those salespeople are under tremendous pressure to upsell and fuck customers out of more money. and as a result they are incredibly unethical.
.
the gal i talked to over the phone only tried to charge me $10/mo above their advertised price for, of all things, a landline (once she realized she couldn't sell me a bundled cable package), and tried to convince me it was a great deal because i get to have a landline i'd never use.
.
don't be afraid to be assertive with these people (note, you can be assertive without being rude or mean, but feel free to try being rude or mean too if you need to! i was super sweet and friendly in a very passive aggressive way). once she was stammering over the benefits of a landline, i was able to take the reign on her sales pitch and discover the hidden internet only option that was actually cheaper than was advertised on their website.
.
she was actually the one who asked me if i was providing my own router, to which i said yes. probably because i became so assertive with her, and already knew what i wanted and what it should cost, she realized it was not worth the stress of trying to upsell me.

@Rek: my problem with seeding tons of sites is that it seems to be throwing a hitch in tor-always-mode, at least for me, at least on the current version, although someone appeared to be working on a fix i  haven't been able to try yet. if other people want to come up with cool alternate home screens, that does sound like a worthwhile endeavor!
@Lmath: that is horrifying

@Rek: if you try it again, note that in tor-always the port is supposed to be closed, and seeding sites should still work normally unless i'm crazy. but i think the mixed mode tor+clearnet, the port still needs to be opened, but i'm not certain.

@Rek: you should be able to seed just fine. in tor-always-mode the port is closed because zeronet doesn't need an open port, all communication is routed through tor hidden services. as long as tor isn't firewalled, the only slowness is coming from the fact that it's being routed through tor. (i think)
@Lmath: its significantly better for me after i removed a couple large (and already well-seeded sites), so i haven't had any real problems as of late.
@Lmath: in tor always mode there should never be any opened ports
oh! i did not know the colon was important lol

i haven't experienced any spam or abusive users on zerome recently but i also can not read chinese and my spanish is rusty, so i may be missing something. now, if you wish to police other people's beliefs and values, you are better off using the mute function. then the things they say can't affect you.
